sec.title: Self-Study Program
sec.p: Reading an issue of the Journal of Correctional Health Care and completing the corresponding exam is considered a single continuing education activity. The self-study exam questions are based on selected articles in this issue. Content is intended to be presented without bias of any commercial product or drug.

You may answer exam questions relating to every article, or you may select questions relating to specific articles. Credit will be awarded for each article, assuming 75% of the questions are answered correctly. Grading of the exam is conducted on a confidential basis by NCCHC staff.

Term of approval requires that exams must be completed and received by NCCHC within 2 years of the distribution date of this publication. Credit may be claimed for this issue of JCHC until January 2014.

sec.title: Learning Objectives
sec.p:
The Journal of Correctional Health Care is the only national, peer-reviewed scientific journal to address correctional health care topics. After participating in this self-study activity, participants should be able to:
Identify and describe trends and developments in the correctional health care field.
Describe case studies and best practices related to the correctional setting and apply them as appropriate.
Discuss empirical research findings, including their relevance and limitations.
Critically evaluate the literature and recent books addressing correctional health or related fields.

sec.title: Continuing Education
sec.p:
Participants should claim only the credit commensurate with the extent of their participation in the activity.
CCHPs: The Certified Correctional Health Professional Board of Trustees has approved this educational activity for 5.25 contact hours of Category 1 credit.
Nurses: The National Commission on Correctional Health Care is an approved provider of continuing nursing education by the Illinois Nurses Association, an accredited approver by the American Nurses Credentialing Center’s Commission on Accreditation. NCCHC designates this activity for a maximum of 5.25 contact hours (INA-CE Approval Number EXT-0811-4026).
Physicians: The National Commission on Correctional Health Care is accredited by the Accreditation Council for Continuing Medical Education to provide continuing medical education for physicians. NCCHC designates this journal-based CME activity for a maximum of 5.25 AMA PRA Category 1 Credit(s)™. Physicians should claim only the credit commensurate with the extent of their participation in the activity.
Psychologists: The National Commission on Correctional Health Care is approved by the American Psychological Association to offer continuing education for psychologists. NCCHC maintains responsibility for the program. NCCHC designates this education activity for up to 5.25 hours.

sec.title: Disclosure Statement
sec.p: In accordance with the disclosure policy of the National Commission on Correctional Health Care, authors, editorial board members, and staff participating in JCHC’s continuing education program are expected to disclose any significant financial interest or other relationship with the manufacturers of commercial products and/or providers of commercial services that might be germane to the content of the articles. Such disclosure is not intended to suggest or condone bias in any article but rather is elicited to provide information that readers might deem important to their evaluation of a given article.
Jason C. Simeone, PhD, coauthor of “An Innovative Approach to Pharmacy Management in a State Correctional System”: receipt of a research grant from Takeda Pharmaceuticals North America, Inc.

No other authors published in this issue of the Journal of Correctional Health Care, nor editorial board members or staff, have reported receiving something of value* from a company whose product may be germane to the content of their article.

* “Something of value” refers to an equity position, receipt of royalties, consultantship, funding by a research grant, receiving honoraria for educational services elsewhere, or any other relationship with a company that provides sufficient reason for disclosure, in keeping with the spirit of the policy.

sec.title: Payment
sec.p: For $30—only $20 for members of the Academy of Correctional Health Professionals—you will receive a certificate of completion indicating the number of hours earned. The self-study exam will not be processed and credit will not be awarded without receipt of payment. There are no refunds or cancellations.

sec.title: Instructions

list-item.p: Read each article and check the correct answer to the corresponding questions on the exam. Each question has one answer that is most correct. Multiple answers for one question will not be counted. Be sure to fully erase all unnecessary marks.
Read the statement at the bottom of the answer sheet after completing the exam and sign to indicate your agreement.
Complete the evaluation to help us monitor the quality of this self-study program.
Mail the completed exam, evaluation, and payment to: NCCHC, PO Box 11117, Chicago, IL 60611. We recommend keeping a copy of the exam for your reference.

sec.p: Journal of Correctional Health Care, Volume 18, Issue 1 Self-Study Exam

Nonviolent Communication and Empathy in Male Parolees (p. 8)
Common psychosocial adaptations that individuals make in response to correctional life include:
Interpersonal distrust and social isolation
Decreased appetite and lethargy
Hyperactivity and intense socialization
Excessive cleanliness and attention to detail
Approximately what percentage of paroled adults return to prison within 3 years of release?
45 to 55
20 to 30
60 to 70
75 to 85
The primary purpose of nonviolent communication is to:
Reduce recidivism
Enhance job-seeking skills
Decrease use of drugs and alcohol
Resolve interpersonal conflict
Community-based participatory research approaches are appropriate for use with the parole population because they ensure that interventions are:
Longitudinal
Multilevel
Relevant
Cost-effective

Recidivism Rates Among Mentally Ill Inmates: Impact of the Connecticut Offender Reentry Program (p. 20)
How long after release from prison is a former offender most likely to reoffend?
30 days
3 months
1 year
3 years
Which of the following is NOT an eligibility criterion for enrolling into the CORP program?
Age 18 or older
6 to 12 months left on prison sentence
Two or more previous incarcerations
Convicted of a serious or violent offense
Which variable was significantly associated with rearrest in this study?
Mental illness
A co-occurring substance abuse disorder
Homelessness
Younger age
What is an important factor to consider when implementing a reentry program?
Specialized treatments specific to the population’s needs
Health status of the participants
Family support
Proximity to community agencies

Compliance With Bloodborne Pathogen Standards at Eight Correctional Facilities (p. 29)
Staff who may be exposed to bloodborne pathogens (BBP) must receive appropriate BBP training:
At time of hire
At time of hire and at least annually thereafter
When they are assigned to work in a medical unit or provide medical treatment
After a BBP exposure has occurred at the facility
For employees who may be exposed to BBP, which of the following statements about the hepatitis B vaccine can be found in the OSHA standards?
The vaccine must be offered by the employer, free of charge, within 10 working days of hire
All employees must be vaccinated if they have potential exposure
Employees should talk to their private physicians before deciding whether to get the vaccine
If an employee declines the vaccine at time of hire, it is the employee’s responsibility to get the vaccine if he later changes his mind
A BBP exposure control plan must document the following topic:
Cost of administration of the exposure control plan
Annual consideration of effective safer medical devices
How many exposures the facility documented in the previous year
The number of inmates with HIV and/or hepatitis C
For exposure plans in correctional facilities, this study found:
Facilities consistently develop and maintain these plans as required
Facilities generally have established exposure control plans, but do not keep them up to date
The facility manager did not personally review and sign the plan
The plan was not always posted to the facility website

Guideline, Education, and Peer Comparison to Reduce Prescriptions of Benzodiazepines and Low-Dose Quetiapine in Prison (p. 45)
Disadvantages of benzodiazepines in prison include all of the following except:
They are subject to abuse
They are subject to diversion
They are expensive
There are less risky alternatives for the treatment of insomnia and anxiety
Disadvantages of low-dose quetiapine in prison include all of the following except:
It is subject to abuse
It can cause metabolic derangements, which can lead to diabetes and cardiovascular disease
It is an ineffective antipsychotic even at higher doses
There are less risky and expensive alternatives for the treatment of insomnia and anxiety
In physician profiling, an individual physician’s practice is compared with _____ to improve quality of care through improved patient outcomes and/or lower cost:
An expert opinion
A benchmark
A managed care formulary
A supervisor
Potential reasons why this study’s intervention was effective include all of the following except:
Physicians respond to social norms (i.e., peer pressure)
The targeted behavior lent itself to modification as it was already controversial among physicians
Clinical guidelines by themselves are effective in changing physicians' behavior
The physicians are salaried employees who understand that supervision and quality improvement initiatives are a standard part of their work

An Innovative Approach to Pharmacy Management in a State Correctional System (p. 53)
Which of the following processes is part of the management function of pharmacy services?
Formulary development
Ordering medication
Delivering medication
Distributing medication to inmates
The Rhode Island Department of Corrections (RIDOC) inmate population is disproportionately affected by which of the following diseases?
Diabetes
Hypertension
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
Psychiatric illnesses
What percentage of inmates housed by the RIDOC is sentenced to 6 months or less?
10%
20%
40%
60%
Under the transitional model, the RIDOC experienced pharmaceutical cost and utilization increases. Which of the following did NOT coincide with those increases?
Service problems (e.g., incorrect orders, stock outages)
Catastrophic care patients (liver transplant, traumatic injury)
Medication waste
Open formulary

Treatment of Odontogenic Pain in a Correctional Setting (p. 62)
Which of the following is an indication for antibiotic therapy for a healthy inmate who presents with a toothache?
Pain of more than 1 week’s duration
Pain on chewing
Extraoral swelling
A large area of decay
An inmate complaining of a toothache should be examined by a midlevel provider, physician, or dentist:
Within 2 weeks
Within 24 hours
Within 72 hours
Within 1 week
The preferred first-line antibiotic for a dental abscess is:
Erythromycin
Tetracycline
Penicillin V
Metronidazole
The source of a dental infection can be removed by:
Extracting the tooth
7 to 10 days of antibiotic therapy
Several regimens of antibiotic therapy
The use of antimicrobial mouth rinses

Exploring Scope of Practice Issues for Correctional Facility Nurses in Montana (p. 70)
What do the nurses in this study perceive as the top priority in the correctional health setting?
Safety
Care
Patient advocacy
Referral to correct specialist
What was the most notable difference between traditional nursing and correctional nursing in this study?
Specialties
Culture of custody
Practice rights
Risks
Of the nurses who participated in the survey, _____ believed correctional nursing has a stigma compared to other nursing specialties.
Few
About one third
About half
About three quarters
What were the limitations mentioned in this study?
The difficult questionnaire
Small sample size and nonprobabilistic design
Unmet assumptions of statistical analyses
Lack of a control group

sec.title: Honor Statement
sec.p: I attest by my signature that I personally have completed this self-study exam.

list-item.p: Certified Correctional Health Professionals
Nurses
Physicians
Psychologists
Nonmember: $30

sec.title: Form of Payment

list-item.p: Check enclosed, payable to NCCHC
MasterCard □ Visa □ Amex

sec.p: For office use only:
_______________ Exam Received
_______________ Certificate Sent
Journal of Correctional Health Care, Volume 18, Issue 1 Self-Study Program Evaluation

tr.td: 1. How well did the articles meet their stated learning objectives?
Poor
Fair
Good
Great

td.bold: Nonviolent Communication and Empathy in Male Parolees

tr.td: •List two psychosocial adaptations that individuals make as a result of their incarceration
•Describe two ways participants used nonviolent communication in their interpersonal relationships
•Articulate two reasons why community-based participatory research approaches are beneficial for research with the parole population

td.bold: Recidivism Rates Among Mentally Ill Inmates: Impact of the Connecticut Offender Reentry Program

tr.td: •Discuss the prevalence of mental illness in the prison population
•Describe characteristics of CORP program participants and of those who received standard treatment planning services
•Identify predictors of recidivism in both groups

td.bold: Compliance With Bloodborne Pathogen Standards at Eight Correctional Facilities

tr.td: •Describe the key components of a bloodborne exposure prevention program
•Assess where an organization’s compliance with bloodborne guidelines may be deficient
•Use health communication materials to raise awareness of proper bloodborne prevention work practices

td.bold: Guideline, Education, and Peer Comparison to Reduce Prescriptions of Benzodiazepines and Low-Dose Quetiapine in Prison

tr.td: •State the disadvantages of benzodiazepines and low-dose quetiapine in prison
•Define the term “physician profiling” and describe how it is used in this study
•Describe how a clinical guideline and peer comparison can be combined to change physicians' prescribing behavior

td.bold: An Innovative Approach to Pharmacy Management in a State Correctional System

tr.td: •Describe differences in how pharmacy services are delivered in federal and state correctional facilities
•Identify the ways that private vendors and academic collaborators may assist in the distributive and management functions of a correctional pharmacy system
•Outline potential steps to implement a pharmacy management system in a state correctional facility

td.bold: Treatment of Odontogenic Pain in a Correctional Setting

tr.td: •Describe the elements of a dental examination for an inmate presenting with a toothache
•Discuss the indications for antibiotic therapy for inmates presenting with toothache pain
•Specify the appropriate antibiotic regimen for inmates for whom antibiotic therapy is indicated

td.bold: Exploring Scope of Practice Issues for Correctional Facility Nurses in Montana

tr.td: •Discuss scope-of-practice issues as reported by Montana correctional nurses
•Describe how the nursing process of assessment in the correctional setting differs from that in a traditional setting
•Explain how the culture of custody differentiates correctional nursing from nursing in a traditional setting
2. Please rate the relevance of the information addressed in each of the articles to your profession.
Poor
Fair
Good
Great
Nonviolent Communication and Empathy in Male Parolees
Recidivism Rates Among Mentally Ill Inmates: Impact of the Connecticut Offender Reentry Program
Compliance With Bloodborne Pathogen Standards at Eight Correctional Facilities
Guideline, Education, and Peer Comparison to Reduce Prescriptions of Benzodiazepines and Low-Dose Quetiapine in Prison
An Innovative Approach to Pharmacy Management in a State Correctional System
Treatment of Odontogenic Pain in a Correctional Setting
Exploring Scope of Practice Issues for Correctional Facility Nurses in Montana

To earn credit for state licensing requirements
To meet employer’s continuing education requirements
To gain a better understanding of the information contained in the articles
Other ______________________________________________________________________

Fair
Good
Great
